facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 841 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 841 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 12, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Application No. 379 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 12, 1961 of the Bombay High Court in Misc. Application No. 379 of 1959.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: Expenditure-tax Act 29 of 1957 received assent of the President on September 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Expenditure-tax Act 29 of 1957 which received the assent of the President on September 17, 1957,

facts.text: Expenditure-tax Act was brought into force on April 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: was brought into force on April 1, 1958.

facts.text: His Highness Mahendrasinghji, Ruler of Morvi died on August 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: His Highness Mahendrasinghji, Ruler of Morvi died on August 17, 1957, having made a will

facts.text: Mahendrasinghji made a will appointing the respondents as executors of his estate.

anchor.surface_text: having made a will appointing the respondents to this appeal as executors of his estate.

facts.text: Expenditure-tax Officer issued a notice under S. 13(2) of the Expenditure-tax Act requiring the respondents to furnish a return of expenditure incurred by Mahendrasinghji for April 1, 1957 to August 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The Expenditure-tax Officer issued a notice under S. 13 2  of the Expenditure-tax Act, 1947, requiring the respondents to furnish a return of the expenditure incurred by Mahendrasinghji for the period between April 1, 1957 to August 17, 1957.

facts.text: Respondents submitted that the Act did not apply to Mahendrasinghji because he died before the Act came into force and executors not liable.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents submitted that the Act did number apply to Mahendrasinghji because he had died before the date on which the Act came into force, and on that account the respondents as executors of his will were number liable to submit the return demanded.

facts.text: Expenditure-tax Officer rejected the contention by letter dated November 19, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: By letter dated November 19, 1959, the Expenditure-tax Officer rejected the companytention raised by the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents filed a petition in Bombay High Court under Art. 226 to quash proceedings and restrain Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then filed a petition in the High Court of Bombay under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying that the proceedings started by the Expenditure-tax Officer for assessing and levying tax on the expenditure incurred by the late Mahendrasinghji during the previous year be quashed and that the Officer be restrained by an injunction from taking further steps or proceedings under the Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held that charge under Act for 1958-59 was on individual incurring expenditure, not estate, and since unit not in existence on April 1, 1958, no tax leviable.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the charge under the Act in respect of expenditure incurred in the relevant previous year to the assessment year 1958-59 was number on the estate of any individual or any Hindu undivided family it was on the individual or the Hindu undivided family incurring the expenditure, and as it was imposed for the first time on April 1, 1958, unless the unit of assessment was in existence on the date when the Act came into force, numbertax companyld be levied.

facts.text: Appeal preferred to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, this appeal has been preferred.

facts.text: Section 18 provides liability on executor to pay tax out of estate of deceased.

anchor.surface_text: Section 18 provides Where a person dies, his executor, administrator or other legal representative shall be liable to pay out of the estate of the deceased person to the extent to which the estate is capable of meeting the charge, the expenditure-tax assessed as payable by such person,

facts.text: Respondents contended Parliament failed to set up machinery for deceased before Act came into force.

anchor.surface_text: It is however submitted that the Parliament has failed to set up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59 so as to render his estate liable under the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held s.18 applies to persons dying before Act came into force.

anchor.surface_text: The expression Where a person dies standing by itself in s. 18 does number suggest that thereby it was intended to refer only to death of the person liable after the Act was brought into force

facts.text: In Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay High Court held assessment cannot continue after death.

anchor.surface_text: In Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , the Bombay High Court held that where a person dies after the issue of a numberice under s. 22 2  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, to make a return of his income, but before he makes a return, assessment proceedings companymenced against him under the Income-tax Act cannot be companytinued

facts.text: Section 24B added to Income-tax Act 1922 by Amendment Act 18 of 1933 effective September 11, 1933.

anchor.surface_text: Section 24B was added in the Income-tax Act, 1922, by the Income-tax  Second Amendment  Act 18 of 1933 with effect from September 11, 1933,

facts.text: In D.N. Mehta case, Avabai died on May 6, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: In D. N. Mehtas case 1  one Avabai died on May 6, 1932 after she was served with a numberice requiring her to make a return of her income under s. 22 2  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Bombay HC in D.N. Mehta held estate not liable if death before amendment.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment of income-tax against her legal representatives it was companytended that Avabai had died before the date on which the amendment was made, her estate was number liable to be taxed under the machinery incorporated in the Act in S. 24B. This companytention found favour with the Bombay High Court

facts.text: Supreme Court disagreed with High Court and held estate liable even if death before Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable therefore to agree with the High Court that by enacting s. 18 of the Act the Parliament has number rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax, if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.

issues.text: Whether the Expenditure-tax Act applies to Mahendrasinghji because he died before the date on which the Act came into force making the respondents as executors liable to submit the return

anchor.surface_text: The respondents submitted that the Act did number apply to Mahendrasinghji because he had died before the date on which the Act came into force, and on that account the respondents as executors of his will were number liable to submit the return demanded.

issues.text: Whether unless the unit of assessment was in existence on the date when the Act came into force no tax could be levied on the charge under the Act in respect of expenditure incurred in the relevant previous year

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the charge under the Act in respect of expenditure incurred in the relevant previous year to the assessment year 1958-59 was number on the estate of any individual or any Hindu undivided family it was on the individual or the Hindu undivided family incurring the expenditure, and as it was imposed for the first time on April 1, 1958, unless the unit of assessment was in existence on the date when the Act came into force, numbertax companyld be levied.

issues.text: Whether the Parliament has failed to set up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59 so as to render his estate liable under the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is however submitted that the Parliament has failed to set up effective machinery for assessing tax against the estate of a person who died during the previous year relevant to the assessment year 1958-59 so as to render his estate liable under the Act.

issues.text: Whether Section 18 of the Expenditure-tax Act brings within the net of taxation cases of persons who died before the Act was brought into force or only sets up machinery for enforcing liability against the estate of a person dying after the Act is brought into force

anchor.surface_text: But counsel for the respondent said that s. 18 of the Expenditure-tax Act does number bring within the net of taxation cases of persons who died before the Act was brought into force it only sets up machinery for enforcing liability against the estate of a person dying after the Act is brought into force.

issues.text: Whether Parliament by adopting the phraseology of s.24B(1) of the Income-tax Act intended to give legislative recognition to the interpretation of s.24B in income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta

anchor.surface_text: Counsel placed strong reliance upon income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta  2  decided by the Bombay High Court, and submitted that Parliament having adopted the same phraseology as was used in I s. 24B  1  of the Income-tax Act, it may be inferred that it was intended to give legislative recognition to the interpretation of  1  5 I.T.C. 100 I.L.R. 55 Bom. 312.  2  3 I.T.R. 147 s.24 insofar as it is applicable to the Expenditure-tax Act.

arguments.claim: Inconvenience of estate distribution does not bar tax liability on deceased's estate under s.18

anchor.surface_text: The argument of inconvenience has numbersubstance. A person who has rendered himself liable to pay tax on the expenditure incurred by him in the previous year may, number being aware of the proposal to enact a statute like the Expenditure-tax Act, part with his estate.

holdings.text: Parliament by enacting s. 18 of the Expenditure-tax Act has rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax, if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable therefore to agree with the High Court that by enacting s. 18 of the Act the Parliament has number rendered the estate of a person liable to expenditure-tax, if such person had died before the date on which the Act was brought into force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court view; s.18(1) declares liability without temporal restriction, s.18(3) applies ss.13-15 machinery to legal representatives for pre-Act deaths.

holdings.text: The expression 'Where a person dies' standing by itself in s. 18 does not suggest that it was intended to refer only to death of the person liable after the Act was brought into force.

anchor.surface_text: The expression Where a person dies standing by itself in s. 18 does number suggest that thereby it was intended to refer only to death of the person liable after the Act was brought into force

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of phrase unrestricted; read with s.18(2)-(3) attracts full charge and machinery to pre-Act deaths.

holdings.text: Section 18 sets up effective machinery for assessing tax on estate of person who died during previous year by sub-s.(1) declaring liability and sub-ss.(2)-(3) empowering notices and applying ss.13,14,15 to legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: In terms, sub-s. 1 of S. 18, imposes liability upon the legal representatives of a person who dies, to pay out of his estate, expenditure-tax assessed as payable by such person, or any sum which would have been payable by him if he had number died.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit provisions in s.18(2)-(3) authorize assessment against legal reps as if deceased alive, rejecting claim of machinery failure.

holdings.text: s.18 clearly expresses intention to cover pre-Act deaths despite identical phraseology to s.24B Income-tax Act and prior Bombay HC interpretations limiting s.24B to post-enactment deaths.

anchor.surface_text: The expression Where a person dies standing by itself in s. 18 does number suggest that thereby it was intended to refer only to death of the person liable after the Act was brought into force and read with the remaining clauses in the companytext of sub-ss. 2 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context differs; Expenditure-tax Act's s.18(3) integrates machinery fully, unlike Income-tax cases; no legislative adoption of narrow view.

holdings.text: Language of s.18 admits of no reasonable doubt in imposing tax on estates of deceased before Act's commencement, satisfying strict construction of taxing statutes.

anchor.surface_text: The principle which must always be applied in companystruing a taxing Act is that the Government must show that the tax sought be recovered has been imposed in language which admits of numberreasonable doubt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges strict construction principle from prior cases but holds s.18 clear in context of subs.(1)-(3).

holdings.text: Inconvenience or hardship from estate distribution does not bar levy of expenditure-tax on deceased's estate under s.18.

anchor.surface_text: The argument of inconvenience has numbersubstance. A person who has rendered himself liable to pay tax on the expenditure incurred by him in the previous year may, number being aware of the proposal to enact a statute like the Expenditure-tax Act, part with his estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Policy argument rejected; statutory liability trumps post-death distribution.

precedents.citation: Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1

anchor.surface_text: In Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , the Bombay High Court held that where a person dies after the issue of a numberice under s. 22 2  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, to make a return of his income, but before he makes a return, assessment proceedings companymenced against him under the Income-tax Act cannot be companytinued and his legal representative will number be liable to pay tax which such person may, if he had number died, have been assessed to pay. In the view of the High Court the definition

precedents.case_name: Ellis Reid v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: where a person dies after the issue of a notice under s. 22(2) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 to make a return but before making the return, assessment proceedings commenced against him cannot be continued and legal representative not liable; definition of assessee applies only to living person
precedents.cited_holding: assessment proceedings companymenced against him under the Income-tax Act cannot be companytinued and his legal representative will number be liable to pay tax which such person may, if he had number died, have been assessed to pay

precedents.citation: income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta 2

anchor.surface_text: Counsel placed strong reliance upon income-tax Commissioner, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta  2  decided by the Bombay High Court, and submitted that Parliament having adopted the same phraseology as was used in I s. 24B  1  of the Income-tax Act, it may be inferred that it was intended to give legislative recognition to the interpretation of  1  5 I.T.C. 100 I.L.R. 55 Bom. 312.  2  3 I.T.R. 147 s.24 insofar as it is applicable to the Expenditure-tax Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. D. N. Mehta
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 24B of Income-tax Act inserted in 1933 does not apply to persons who died before the amendment; opening words 'Where a person dies' more appropriate to future deaths not past; no retrospective effect; liability inchoate before amendment crystallised only then
precedents.cited_holding: the Amendment Act merely deals with machinery it does for the first time impose an enforceable liability. The opening words of each sub-section to Section 24-B Where a person dies... seem to me more appropriate to future than to past deaths. If the Legislature had intended the Act to have a retrospective effect, it would have been very easy to have said, dies whether before or after the passing of this Act.
